cross_domain_references.note: This AKU APPLIES concepts from neurology, psychology, pharmacology, and public health. The authoritative definitions live in those native domains.

applies.applicationContext: Dehydration impairs cognitive performance. At conferences, proactive hydration (200-300ml every 60-90 minutes) prevents cognitive decline.
Jet lag disrupts circadian rhythms. Travelers should plan for 1 day recovery per time zone and use strategic light exposure.
Strategic 10-20 minute naps during circadian dip (1-3 PM) restore alertness without causing sleep inertia.
Decision fatigue accumulates throughout conference days. Pre-planning reduces trivial decisions and preserves capacity.
FOMO at conferences is managed through intentional priority-setting and accepting that missing sessions is inevitable.
Caffeine timing matters: avoid 6+ hours before intended sleep, delay morning coffee 90-120 minutes after waking.
Break up sitting every 30-60 minutes during conference sessions to prevent metabolic harm.

definition.@value: An applied guidance document synthesizing research from neurology, psychology, pharmacology, and public health to optimize cognitive performance during conferences and business travel. This is an APPLICATION DOMAIN document - authoritative scientific content lives in the referenced native domain AKUs.

pre_conference: Begin sleep schedule shift 3 days before (eastward = earlier, westward = later)
Plan session schedule and priorities in advance (reduces decision fatigue)
Pack: water bottle, artificial tears, noise-canceling headphones, eye mask
during_conference: Drink 200-300ml water every 60-90 minutes (before thirst develops)
Take 15-20 minute power nap during 1-3 PM dip if needed
Delay morning caffeine 90-120 minutes; cut off 6+ hours before bed
Limit alcohol to 1-2 drinks; stop 3+ hours before bed
mindset: Accept that you cannot attend everything (JOMO over FOMO)
Quality of engagement > quantity of sessions
Rest serves performance better than over-scheduling
